summary:
I do believe that we are here to contribute, to make a better world. 

My goal is to support and facilitate transformations to meet the needs of all people within the means of this living planet. Sustainable, fair, and inclusive changes that reach and empower those people who need it most.

For the last eight years, I have had the opportunity to be part of multicultural and multisectoral teams in Latin America, Asia, and Europe. In addition, I worked with a wide range of actors such as farmers, cooperatives, companies, NGOs, and research centers with a clear purpose in mind: to contribute to improving the livelihoods of vulnerable populations.

profile_positions.description:
I am actively collaborating on two themes as part of the CORE-Africa project team: inputs and services for farmers and resilience. 

By understanding how inputs and services are delivered, cross-cutting learning can be built to improve performance and value creation. We are working closely with the Springfield Center, as a knowledge partner, to gain a better understanding by applying market scans and service delivery models under three main lenses.

Recent crises have made us look at resilience as a way to systemically analyze the factors and their linkages with each other to gain a better understanding of the situation. However, it is a complex, broad and slippery concept. We are working towards making resilience more concrete and specific by developing a simple but rich conceptual framework. This framework will be validated in various themes and settings.

The COVID-19 Response and Resilience Initiative for Food Value Chains in Africa (CORE-Africa) project seeks to strengthen responses to the COVID-19 situation of nine projects across Africa (Ethiopia, Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Mali, Burkina Faso, Rwanda, and Burundi) and to capture lessons for interventions and policies.

CORE-Africa addresses five key themes: 
- Inputs and services for farmers
- Consumer market channels
- Digitalization for agriculture
- Hygiene integration
- Resilience (cross-cutting topic)
profile_positions.title: Agriculture Value Chains Advisor

profile_positions.description:
I contribute to the Impact at Scale (I@S) Program team by conducting qualitative data generation and analysis as well as analytical writing of the Scaling Scan and Scaling Readiness Reports. 

The I@S Program is responsible for supporting the scaling-up of innovations of all International Livestock Research Institute (ILRI) programs. The program draws on the expertise and experience of staff from across ILRI’s programs based in 16 African and Asian countries who have an in-depth understanding of the local contexts and direct access to local partners. In addition, it provides inputs into scaling, projected benefits, and performance and results at One CGIAR level.
profile_positions.title: Scaling Consultant

company.name: Environmental Change Institute (ECI), University of Oxford

profile_positions.company: Environmental Change Institute (ECI), University of Oxford
profile_positions.description:
The central theme of my research was to understand the role that foresight plays in the transition of food systems. Foresight can be an engaging and systemic tool that supports exploration, analysis, and understanding of the challenges facing our food system. In addition, it is a collaborative and horizontal approach that invites actors from various sectors, in order to enrich the processes under their diverse perspectives.

Thesis Topic: The role of foresight in the transition of the food system governance considering practitioners’ perspective

The Foresight4Food initiative is organized by the Food Systems Group of the Institute for Environmental Change at the University of Oxford. Foresight4Food seeks to intelligently engage citizens and leaders in a better understanding of what is currently going on, what the future consequence would be, and what might be alternative pathways with more desirable outcomes.
profile_positions.title: Research Intern

profile_positions.description: I assisted professors with supervision and assessment of the BSc students in the course "Strategic Change Management and Innovation" led by the Education and Learning Sciences (ELS) and Business Management and Organization (BMO) Chairgroups.
profile_positions.title: Teaching Assistant

profile_positions.description:
I collaborated in the elaboration of a three-country study, which aimed to provide insight into the national initiatives, policies, sector strategies, and multi-stakeholder mechanisms, which as a whole shape and sustain opportunities for the sustainable transformation of food systems.

I supported the identification of policies, sector strategies, capacities, and multi-stakeholder mechanisms in the Costa Rica food system. Likewise, I conducted interviews with key actors who foster sustainable food systems transition. I also contributed to the analysis and writing phase of the case study. And finally, I facilitated the workshop to socialize the preliminary findings.

Wageningen Centre for Development Innovation brings knowledge on food systems into action, by strengthening capacities for sustainable development in upcoming markets.
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant

profile_positions.description:
I supported remotely the process of conducting a market study for buffalos, pigs, and cattle in Son La province located in the region of North-West Vietnam. The aim of the project was to provide empirical evidence for improving interactions and structures within livestock value chains. 

From my position as an intern, I contributed to the elaboration of the protocol and the instruments of the market survey executed by the team in the intervention area. Likewise, I supported the review of data and I carried out the analysis of primary and secondary data.

The market study was part of the Livestock CRP priority country work in the Livestock and Livelihoods Agri-Food Systems (LLAFS) flagship. Besides, this internship was linked with Wageningen University and Research (WUR) through the Entrepreneurial Learning in Inclusive Agribusiness (ELIA) project.
profile_positions.title: Market Study Intern

company.name: Institute of Development and Environment  - IDMA

profile_positions.company: Institute of Development and Environment  - IDMA
profile_positions.description:
The Program for Agrarian Training and Support for Youth Entrepreneurship in Peru (FORMAGRO) was designed with the aim of improving access and the quality of education in remote rural areas, improving and diversifying agricultural production, as well as facilitating access to the market of young agricultural producers. FORMAGRO had three key pillars: training, production, and entrepreneurship.

The entrepreneurship pillar was executed from various angles. My role was to design and implement strategies and actions for commercial assistance to youth agricultural enterprises. For example, I was part of the design of the Wiñay Fund, which sought to provide seed capital to young people to accelerate their business growth.

Likewise, I structured organized, and facilitated workshops and capacity-building sessions for commercial advice that was provided to young entrepreneurs. Also, I provided technical assistance to other facilitators.

Besides I collaborated in the articulation with public and private institutions that also promoted the development of sustainable and inclusive markets and/or work with youth. We looked to make partnerships with municipalities and organizations that will add value to FORMAGRO´s objective.
profile_positions.title: Commercial Advisor

profile_positions.description:
My function was to promote the joint work of small businesses in the chocolate sector within the Lima region. Therefore, there was a process of trust-building between the participants that took place over 6 months. Among the activities carried out was the identification of business opportunities in the commercial chain of chocolate and derivatives, the facilitation of the process for the creating of two business networks, the implementation of joint actions of the two networks (training workshops, participation in fairs, markets among others) And finally, there was detailed monitoring and evaluation of the networks in the process of management and consolidation of their joint business.

This project was a pilot executed by HELVETAS and financed by the Ministry of Production of Peru in order to measure the feasibility of promoting the use of this strategy on a larger scale. The project focused on three sectors: mechanic, chocolate, and alpaca fiber in the region of Lima and Arequipa.
profile_positions.title: Business Network Advisor

profile_positions.description: I did the diagnosis of factors to be evaluated in youth (15 - 35 years old) involved in the coffee and cocoa chains in Peru. Subsequently, I accompanied the fieldwork of the implementation of the "Study of the current situation of rural youth in the coffee and cocoa sector" carried out by external consultants in the departments of San Martín, Cajamarca, and Junín.
profile_positions.title: Youth Consultant

profile_positions.description:
I carried out the diagnosis and analysis of the banana and cocoa value chain in order to measure the levels of inclusiveness in trade relations in both chains, using the LINK methodology developed by CIAT. For this reason, I visited the cooperatives involved and facilitated workshops on key topics such as costs, business models, value chains, among others. I proposed strategies to improve the level of inclusiveness in these chains as well as systematized the experiences of both inclusive businesses.

RIKOLTO is a Belgian development organization that seeks to contribute to viable livelihoods of family farmers in low- and middle-income countries.
profile_positions.title: Inclusive Business Consultant

profile_positions.description:
The Center for Ethics and Social Responsibility (CERS) of the Pacifico Business School had to create the “University Social Responsibility Guide for Latin America” financing by the Development Bank of Latin America (CAF).

My role within the team was to review relevant literature on the subject; as well as preparing proposals for the guide's roadmap, which was an instrument developed for the URSULA network (Union of Latin American University Social Responsibility).
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant

volunteer_experiences.description:
In 2012, the Agriculture Ministers of the G20 called for the creation of a Tropical Agriculture Platform (TAP) to promote the development of national capacities for agricultural innovation in the tropics, where almost all low-income countries are located.

The aim of TAP is to enhance the overall performance of Agriculture Innovation Systems (AIS), with a particular focus on small and medium-scale producers and enterprises in the agribusiness sector. TAP’s ultimate objective is to make agriculture more sustainable and improve livelihoods.

Due to my active role in YPARD (Young Professionals for Agricultural Development), I was chosen to represent them in TAP. I have participated in different meetings such as the 7th TAP Partners Assembly, where we revised our goals as a team. As well, TAP has given me the opportunity to exchange ideas and share experiences with a diverse range of stakeholders who work to improve sustainability on the agricultural sector

Young Professionals for Agricultural Development (YPARD) is an international movement by youth that operates as a network and seeks to engage young people in the construction of more inclusive, fair, and sustainable development in the agricultural sector.

I had the pleasure to work with a committed and diverse group of young volunteers who sought to advocate for the role of youth in the field and the importance of sustainable management in the agricultural sector. As well as, to build capacities in young Peruvians interested in obtaining theoretical and practical experience to have a better understanding of the challenges in agricultural development.

During my leadership, we launched the II Rural Youth School, the I Agrarian Symposium: situation of youth and prospects 2030 and we were an active member of the Research Group under the theme: rural youth and territories led by the Institute of Peruvian Studies (IEP) and financed by the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD)
